case_title: JEHAD ALI vs RIAZ ALI AND ANOTHER

accussed_details.name: Jehad Ali
allegation: Murder of Mst. Shagufta under Section 302(b), PPC

complaint_summary: Riaz Ali reported that Jehad Ali shot his sister Mst. Shagufta after an altercation over taking her minor son to the field.
investigation_summary: Investigation conducted by Muhammad Khan included site plan preparation, recovery of blood-stained earth, garments, and weapon. FIR No. 506 registered at Police Station Kalu Khan.
judgment_summary: The court found the prosecution's case doubtful due to lack of independent corroboration, unreliable witness testimony, and absence of key evidence. The conviction and sentence of life imprisonment were set aside, and the appellant was acquitted.
punishment: Conviction and sentence of life imprisonment under Section 302(b), PPC, along with fine of Rs. 300,000 under Section 544-A, Cr.P.C., were set aside.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; conviction and sentence set aside; appellant acquitted.
legal_arguments: Defense argued that the occurrence was unseen and based on suspicion.
Prosecution relied on witness testimony, medical evidence, and recovery of weapon.
Court found prosecution evidence insufficient and witnesses unreliable.

witness_statement.PW-9: Riaz Ali claimed presence at the scene but admitted no special occasion for visit.
witness_statement.PW-10: Noor-ul-Basar admitted visiting deceased's house only twice, including the day of occurrence.
witness_statement.DW-1: Mst. Nusrat testified in defense of the appellant.

key_issues: Absence of key evidence (e.g., empty shells)
Prosecution's failure to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt

maxims.Benefit of Doubt: It is better that ten guilty persons be acquitted rather than one innocent person be convicted.

words_and_phrases.Benefit of Doubt: Rule of prudence favoring acquittal in cases of uncertainty.
words_and_phrases.Unimpeachable Evidence: Evidence that is trustworthy and convincing.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved the murder of Mst. Shagufta allegedly by her brother-in-law, Jehad Ali. The prosecution relied on witness testimony and circumstantial evidence, but the court found the evidence insufficient and unreliable. The appellant was acquitted based on benefit of doubt.

external_wounds: Firearm entry wound above right eye
Firearm exit wound on right side of head

issues: Presence at the scene was doubtful

investigation_flaws: No empty shells recovered from the scene
Statements of other house occupants not recorded

legal_principles.benefit_of_doubt: Prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. Suspicion cannot replace proof.
legal_principles.reliance_on_evidence: Conviction must be based on unimpeachable and corroborated evidence.
